TopicTitle: Docking: relative rotational angle advice requested!

Articles.Content:
Greetings!

I've been putting some objects of non-descript scientific value up in space, and have been docking them together with the intent of it looking like a space station. However, as the docking ports do not seem to lock at a certain angle, I've been using quad docks, so I can at least choose how to rotate the parts at 90 degree intervals.

However, using this quad port setup is quite a hassle, and with the release of the big docking ports I thought I'd ask for some advice from the professionals. Should I stick to my quads, or switch to the big ones?

-Is there a way to get the two objects perfectly lined up on the ROTATIONAL axis? I'm not talking about lining them up for docking, I'm talking about getting them both to have their bellies in the same direction, if you will.

-I've seen a lot of gorgeous space stations out here. How did you guys line it up properly?

-Is mechjeb capable of doing this somehow?

Found an option in mechjeb, under the smartass/surf section, that allows rotational angles. So if both ships do this, one can somewhat reliably dictate the docking angle. Is there any other way though?
Lazor Docking Cam has a rotation indicator, which makes it easy to get a perfect cardinal alignment.
i line mine up manually using the q and e keys once i line up my approach and am on the way for the last 10m or so.

If you still enjoy docking manually, I can second the Lazor Docking cam. Not only does it give you a decent view as you get close, but it has a few readouts that give useful information as you are lining things up.
